commentBody:
My five favorite original clues from last week
(in order of appearance):

1. Fly ball?  (5)
2. Word after one fell?  (5)
3. Contribute to a company, say  (3)
4. Garden-variety poker?  (5)
5. A little bit of everything?  (6)


SWARM
SWOOP
ACT
THORN
SESAME
Unoriginal and too easy. 3/10.
Another ‚ÄúI did it.  But I don‚Äôt get it‚Äù puzzle. 17 minutes
This was great fun!  I loved the Mendel clue and answer(s).
Nicely put together puzzle with a cute revealer.  I liked morel support as the clue for STEM. Bonus points for working in the word CINEASTE

I plugged in ARCHERS before getting to the revealer - so seeing ACES was so fun 

Thank you Jeffrey and Will !

Great Wednesday puzzle.  

But also worried about what that means for tomorrow.  23 hours until we are intentionally deceived.

So these are sort of like kangaroo words, right? Except the subset word isn‚Äôt quite a synonym of the whole, but it‚Äôs congruent to the whole via a common clue they share.

What should this be called:
Wombat words?
Koala words?
Bandicoot words?
Clever and fun. Well done.
Lots of fun, some tricky cluing. Never thought I‚Äôd see Sylvan ESSO in a crossword!
Delightful!

This went very fast, and I regret it, because the theme was so cleverly done.  I wish the overall puzzle were a bit harder so I had more time to savor how good the double "odd" answers were.  The rest of it felt like a Monday to me.

We are fortunate to have such clever constructors featured here (most of the time if you catch my drift without directly raising how bad Sunday's puzzle was again).  :)

Good work, and thanks.

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)
Love these types of puzzles. Feel it would be better thought of the grayed boxes would only be revealed after solving to increase the ‚ÄúAHA!‚Äù moment.

I wasn't sure if I was going to see you frolicking in the meadow, but I took a gambol.

(Still, it's pasture bedtime.)

A couple of quibbles about a fun puzzle.
1A: while POSY might now have expanded in meaning to include ‚Äúflower‚Äù (c.f. MW, but not recognised by the OED) at the time of creation of the rhyme, no later than 1840, it had only its original meaning of ‚Äúsmall bunch of flowers.‚Äù This makes for a disagreement in number between clue and answer. 
 23A: the Advanced Aerospace Threat Identification has been concerned with UAPs (Unexplained anomalous phenomenon) since 2023

Nice puzzle. 

Only quibble: the clue for ISAW could/should  have been in the past tense. 

UPS took a while to click. My bad. The Mendel one gave it away for me. 

Thanks.

Great puzzle!  Enjoyed very much. 

But another quibble:  ‚ÄúROGER‚Äù (5D) in radio communications means only that the person saying it -received- the prior message.  It doesn‚Äôt indicate comprehension, compliance, agreement, or anything beyond reception.  So ‚Äúunderstood‚Äù isn‚Äôt an accurate clue. 

Mark (pilot and occasional user of ‚Äúroger‚Äù üòä)

This was, in my memory, the best crafted crossword in the NYT in *quite* a while. To me, at least, it seemed exceptionally tight in its construction. The fact that the clue/answer pairs worked both ways, both with the trick and without, was *really* nice.

Note to constructors: This was an example of cleverness meeting elegance. Bravi to the constructors!

Nice theme. Got caught up for a while because I took way to long to realize that the Cartesian clue was IAM and not suM. Then a fair bit of time to correct pUTZ to YUTZ when I didn't get the Gold Star.

SITUATION / STAIN didn't wow me. I think of a stain as the aftermath of a mess, not the mess itself. A mess is a situation? I guess - situation is a broad term. Sticky situation? OK.

The others were tight and clever.

When you think about it, Drew TREES is a much better name for a guy: GREEN (like PEAS), in a way, and so artistically evocative. You see, an uncaffeinated mind CONSIDERs THE ODDS of TBA being the answer to ‚ÄúCheck back later,‚Äù in brief, and discards it because it‚Äôs stuck on textspeak for some just-now-torn-from-a-REM-cycle reason. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs another way of saying TTYL,‚Äù said mind muses, patting itself on the back in ways heretofore unknown to neuroanatomists as it affirms to itself that it would never, ever but ever, use textspeak itself. Even if it had fingers. Which it doesn‚Äôt, self-administered back-slapping notwithstanding. Because it is an elusive and diaphanous mystery that defies anatomical reduction and scoffs at the sterile logic of Cartesian dualism, spun as it is from the gossamer threads of the cosmos itself‚Äî

Ah, sorry about that. Coffee truly is a prerequisite for coherent posting. 

Anyhow, ‚ÄúIf not TTYL, surely TTA has been used for Talk To [ya] After?‚Äù says my sleepy mind. And immediately answers (again, this us all pre-morning-coffee), ‚ÄúSure it has.‚Äù

And that‚Äôs how my puzzle came to take an extra x minutes of flyspecking until an old echo of hubby‚Äôs NFL games blaring out of the family room offered up Drew BREES. 

A shoutout to my adopted hometown, Seattle, and a goodnight to my fellow WordplayASTEs. 

Time to start the day.

I enjoyed this puzzle, even though initially I was put off by the multiple trivia entries, especially the trivia nexus in the NW. In the end I needed only two lookups. I managed to recall many answers I have learned from NYT puzzles over the past 18 months, like RADON TESTS (unknown in Poland, as far as I know) and RBI. Good to know my memory is better than I usually think it is.

The theme was pretty neat.
I enjoyed this puzzle a lot, but cin√©aste really primarily means filmmaker - not film buff.
I just got 18 and 20 across and I'm SO IMPRESSED. I filled 18 (thanks, A-level biology) and said 'Really?! No way!' out loud, and confirmed the theme with 20. This is surely a hall-of-famer.
Just finished, incredible. Couldn't be more delighted. Besides the themed clues being works of art, I'd like to thank the constructor for 'morel support'. I think I'm in love.
Absolutely everything I know about baseball comes from doing this crossword.
Since you have an international following, fewer name brands might be helpful, or at least international ones.
Jeffrey and Will are another dynamic duo.  What an excellent theme idea and a perfect implementation.  Not a stretch among them.

Resisted POSY for a long time, since it's always been a small bunch of flowers hereabouts--- as carried by some bridesmaids.
I was also unhappy with LASED. It's the laser emitter that lases, when it emits the light---an ugly back formation, but well established. The thing that is zapped (like my detached retina) is lasered. Or so it goes in ophthalmological circles in my part of the world.

Wow. Typical Wednesday workout for me. Managed to finish it but have to admit that I remained puzzled about the theme until I stopped and pondered for a while. What a great 'aha' moment when it finally dawned on me. Can't help but wonder how many other possibilities there could be. I mean - every one of these with the alternate letters. That's just amazing. 

Oh, and of course I'll put my puzzle find today in a reply. 

...

I like a puzzle with a lot of theme entries, so had fun with this one.  It also seemed just about right for a Wednesday .  

I bet Jeffrey and Will could do a great Thursday puzzle as well.

Odd puzzle.
Evenly clued.
Oddly enjoyable.
Even entertaining!

I don‚Äôt feel like I did after thanksgiving day dessert-

PaInEd.


(It‚Äôs early. 
And I‚Äôm not nearly as clever as Jeffrey and Will.)

Always happy to see an Eeyore reference in the puzzle.  Enjoyed the chewiness of this puzzle and I admit to getting stuck in the SAW/WORSE corner. 
Thanks guys.

Language quirks like what Jeffrey and Will found set me agog as a kid, and still do today.  I jawdrop and ‚ÄúHuh!‚Äù at finds like this.  Then, when they are all tied together with a revealer that perfectly lands, and set in a grid with spark like CINEASTE and FRAZZLE, and clean as a whistle, I slowly nod side to side with respect and gratitude.

I wish EASES had been EESES, which would have been a stellar revealer for the mini-theme of double-E‚Äôs, of which there are eight.  Oh, and I did love [Morel support] for stem.  Double bravo on that.

Thank you, Jeffrey and Will.  Your puzzle started my day with a big ‚ÄúAin‚Äôt life grand?‚Äù, and that is a gift!

A few words about stuckness in solving a crossword puzzle.  I love it for two reasons.  First, when the answer finally comes I feel happy and proud and good.  And second, the kind of brainwork involved in getting from stuck to unstuck ‚Äì that makes my brain come alive in a most wonderful way.

I came across this poem by Wendell Berry, not written about crosswording per se, but it so beautifully applies to that second point.  I‚Äôm hoping some readers here will relate to it as I did, grateful for its beauty and wisdom:


THE REAL WORK

It may be that when we no long know what to do
we have come to our real work
and that when we no longer know which way to go
we have come to our real journey
The mind that is not baffled is not employed
The impeded stream is the one that sings

WORSE for the gold.

Fun solve fellows.

Thank you

Found the theme more forced than interesting. Got it immediately with GrEeNpEaS, which was the only thematic entry that didn't seem contrived. Solved this one easily enough, but didn't find it particularly enjoyable or clever. Even the revealer seemed weak to me. Would have sent this one back.

A very satisfying puzzle, particularly in light of recent offerings.  
This puzzle offers two different theme answers for each starred clue!  All of them provide elegant sets of answers.   Knew we were gonna be thrilled when we ran into Mendel.  And of course if you're stuck all the crosses work out smoothly as well.

A good tight puzzle reveals even more ways to solve as you proceed.  As you proceed, your work should continue to confirm that you are on the right track.  That is why the crosses are so important in a 'crossword puzzle'.   They provide a cross check.  Any puzzle that eliminates the opportunity to use the crosses is by definition inelegant. 
This puzzle was a great example of breezy fun.

Thank you to Jeffrey & Will
That was fantastic. I loved Saturday‚Äôs puzzle and I loved today‚Äôs puzzle. I can‚Äôt remember the last time I enjoyed two puzzles so much so close together.

I love how the theme entries had two layers of meaning--the first being the whole word and the second being the word formed by the letters in the gray squares. I enjoyed this puzzle even though I messed up in the southwest corner for eye exam and send help?
Had a real 63A in the SW with my saD/Mao cross.  As someone said, objectively, "check your assumptions" .  Great puzzle and many thanks.

Morel support? tickled my funny bone.
Odds are, our fungi Mike will have the puns mushrooming up.

Thanks, Jeffrey and Will, for a quick and lively Wednesday puzzle.

Anyone else find the theme answers strangely uneven in quality?

And yet, overall, somehow it worked for me.
Clever puzzle -- though technically, the term  "gene" wasn't coined until decades after Mendel's work - what he really studied was inheritance, being too early to study the biology behind it.

Strands #290 ‚ÄúYou say you want a revolution‚Äù üü°üîµüîµüîµ üîµüîµüîµ I do. Earworm launched. https://music.youtube.com/watch?v=6MbqzDm1uCo Avoid spoilers, please, until "view all replies" button.

Let's start with the obvious:
Great theme; extremely clever.  Hats off to the constructors!

And now the pedantic nit-picking:
I, like many who have already commented, think of POSY as a bunch of flowers or bouquet.
Granted, as others have noted that POSY *can* mean a single flower, nevertheless the clue is "Flower in a children's rhyme." 
The rhyme, I assume, is "pocket full of POSY".  A pocket full of a single flower???
I think not.

As I hope is clear, pedantic nit-picking aside, this was a fine puzzle with a cleverly executed theme.
Congratulations to Jeffrey Martinovic and Will Nediger!
Morel support? and Sending help? were worth the price of admission.

I feel like I'm seeing spots....This is clever construction, and it's not Jeffrey Martinovic's  and Will Nediger's fault if the messy-looking grid makes it heard to look at....  Then again....

New word:  CINEASTE....  perfect for the dustbin.  
YUTZ? Oy.

I've never heard of "The Texas Triangle" despite having lived in that state, but "southwest" and SAN- were pretty good hints.  We spent a whole summer there *without a/c* in 1956, when our dad had TDY at Ft. Sam Houston.  This was so long ago that the newspaper vending arrangement was a cigar box on top of a stack of papers, for folks to drop their coins in.  

RADON LEVEL had to be revised...

Last night I watched Sherrod Brown's farewell speech on the floor of the Senate chamber.  For me, he will always be more than a FOOTNOTE.

This goes out to @CQ, (who has stopped in for minute to comment on "gene", and will hopefully stop back again), concerning the dispute we had over the abbreviation "cres." for crescendo, used in Sunday's puzzle.

I Admit I Was Wrong--(I'd do all caps, but the emus don't like shouting.)

I looked back over the Google Image results for "cres in musical notation,' and yes, there were some--some in holograph manuscripts, some in printed editions; but all 18th-19th c.--IOW, the octopodes of musicology. (Interestingly, one was written as "cres:" rather than "cres.")

Nevertheless, "cresc." has been the standard abbreviation for more than a century; if I came across  "cres." in a modern printed score, I would surely know what was intended, but I would question the quality and professionalism of the composer/editor/publisher. (And trust me, there are some pretty bad engraving jobs out there!)

The exception being a scholarly publication which was intended to reproduce exactly an earlier edition.

Once I had FRAZZLE/FAZE and  GREEN PEAS/GENES, I wondered if I'd be able to get the other theme answers without crosses, but I couldn't -- not even close.  This is what I often try to do when a theme is doing something quite intricate and clever, but that fails to involve me in any way.  I try to do myself what I wish the constructor(s) had done: make the puzzle impossible to solve without figuring out the trick -- whatever the trick is.

Here, we're told exactly that: we'll need to understand the trick to "fully appreciate each starred clue."  Appreciate it, not solve it.

Still, I'm not completely unhappy that I didn't have to work all that hard this morning.  A printout of Lewis's crunchy LAT puzzle arrived by snail mail late yesterday and I haven't fully recovered from wrestling with it.  So my little gray cells were perhaps too tired for another big challenge today.  This puzzle was cleverly conceived and executed, but pretty easy when all is said and done.
Fun and interesting, oddly enough. Nice job, guys!

Another fun solve, just the right amount of difficulty for a Wednesday morning. Not sure about 1A ("Isn't it missing an 'E'?") but ok. 46A was a fun get. I didn't know that radon tests were still a thing; we did those in the 80s and 90s, and now I never hear about them.

THIS AWFUL PUZZLE OBJECTIVELY WAS NOT REALLY THAT CREATIVE

[Reaction to this crossword that could be a themer if the theme referred to words instead of letters]



And if you're wondering which one was my reaction, consider that I'm nothing if not odd.
I could have had a personal best but I struggled with 59 across and 60 down. I have never seen Rent and never heard of VIM as PEP‚Ä¶ Oh well.
A thoroughly enjoyable Wednesday outing. Just crunchy enough to make me pause occasionally, with a lovely Aha feeling when I got the theme. Delightful.

I still can't get my head around CINEASTE, as I can't think of any other word ending in -aste. Anybody? The only thing that comes close is "enthusiast." (Enthousiaste, in French.) Did we just borrow a French word for people who bristle at being called a "movie buff?"

Another clever puzzle, although just a tad bit form over substance. I marvel at how much must have gone into constructing the word-within-a-word theme, however the fill was not that challenging for a Wednesday.
It's uncanny that for two days in a row I've matched my best time to the second!

Very clever and enjoyable puzzle, favorite clue "Sending help?". I stared at UP_  and still wasn't sure of answer, and even after filling it in, still didn't understand it right away, love that! Sam explained it, and love her tip about emphasizing other word, will remember that. Thanks to the constructors!

I enjoyed this one, with just a little Wednesday crunch. My last spot was that small SW corner where I went back and forth with FIfi vs. FIDO, and I See instead of I SAW, partly because I was having trouble with the eye exam clue. Seemed like a perfect Wednesday level puzzle, with some surprises. 
Now I am trying to figure out what Sam‚Äôs image is about. What exactly is that guy staring at? Maybe someone mentioned it already but I don‚Äôt have time to read all the comments, as it‚Äôs Christmas baking day.

"Obit." but no abbreviation in the prompt is a clear rule break in my opinion. Plus: I have never heard "Cineaste" before, that one seems a bit forced but eh, the theme with the "consider the odds" gimmick was fun.

I liked this. No word checks which I did do last Friday and Saturday. I forget if I did it, Thursday. For a while I did no look-ups because I wanted to impress my mother(in my own mind) but yeah something happened September/October that scared me a lot and I couldn‚Äôt focus as well. And now ‚Äúcheck word‚Äù in the later part of the week.
(Thursday I don‚Äôt recall if I do). In a way it saves time but in a way it takes longer! So yes it‚Äôs IF Friday or Saturday are hard or not easy. I‚Äôll let you know if I do a hard Friday or Saturday/no checks but that would be a more patient üòä speed!
Very clever!

"Almost Live" (old sketch comedy TV show) had a parody game show "Pike or Pine" where contestants were tasked with answering "Seattle toughest question" (the streets run next to each other downtown and it's apparently hard to keep them straight).
Cinephile was my first thought regarding 8 down.

Very clever Wednesday puzzle. Enjoyed it very much though I took an inordinately unhealthy amount of time to figure out ISAW and UPS.

Which is funny because I 'didn't see' and was desperate for someone to 'send help'. Tee-hee. 

Yup, I know. There's a lot more where that came from. I'm here every Mon-Sun. ü§£

An interesting and, at times, confounding puzzle, but well constructed and thought out.

I would only quibble with GREENPEAS as fill.  It is usually referred to as gardenPEAS.  After all, one of the seven  traits studied by Mendel was seed color.  The peas were not only green, but also a certain percentage observed were yellow.

Fun puzzle today! 

And thank you, Sam, for this: ‚Äúquestion-mark clues can often be solved by shifting the emphasis to another word.‚Äù While I understood this to be true, I‚Äôd never articulated it quite so succinctly. 

Now, could anyone suggest a similarly pithy way to think of clues that end in ‚Äúsay‚Äù or ‚Äúin a way‚Äù?
Are radon tests a US thing?

Loved the main puzzle, a perfect Wednesday effort. I do, however, take an exception to the Mini‚Äôs 1-across clue. We trombonists often encounter alto clef in the 1st part in classical and romantic orchestral literature. Many Russian composers even scored both the 1st and 2nd parts in alto. Perhaps it‚Äôs implied that the clue meant the only instrument that ‚Äúalways‚Äù reads alto clef?

@Lewis 

Largely agreed.  To my taste #2 is far superior, followed by #1 and then maybe #3.  The others, while good, aren't really in the same class...


____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

Mimi in "La Boheme" wasn't a seamstress. She sold flowers.
@B

@B -- These are not arranged in order of quality, but rather, in order of appearance.  Like you, I greatly loved #2.





Et tu, emu.

@Lewis 

Oh yes, I had noted your "order of appearance" disclaimer.  I was simply giving my two cents about which I liked best.  :)


____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

@B -- Oh, I'm sorry I misinterpreted you!  And, echoing you again, there were clues that I liked better than #4 and #5 (though I did like those two a good amount), it turns out they had been used before.

@George 

"Unoriginal" how? Which part have you seen before?

@George 

Seriously??
@George are you referring to your own comment?
Hey gang, take it easy on @George. He got teased at our Mensa meeting tonight. Means well!

@George 

It's only Wednesday.
They are saving up for the later-week salvo.

The fun is where you find it.
Sorry you missed out.  I guess some of us were just hard up.  I'll thnk twice before I enjoy a mushroom joke again!

@Indiana Bee 
Yes, GREENPEAS brought me a smile. Reminded me of  last 6/22/2024 when the clue was [Plants used in early genetics experiments] which solved to SWEETPEAS. It created quite the stir with discussion of species of pea plants, Punnett Squares, and Jolly Green Giant frozen ‚Äúsweet peas‚Äù. This time they kept it simple, just like last month‚Äôs reference to Pisum Sativum ,11/9/2024.

@Marshall Walthew 

This is only the third time CINEASTE has been in a NYT puzzle. You‚Äôd think all those vowels would make it attractive to constructors.

@Marshall Walthew 

And right next to it another robust, and underused, word, morose.

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

@Cat Lady Margaret 

Oddonyms?

@Cat Lady Margaret 

Symbiotes?


____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

@Cat Lady Margaret 

Leapfroggles.


Obviously.


üê∏

@Charles Nelson Reilly 

I‚Äôve seen Sylvan ESSO at least once before in a crossword puzzle, but it was probably the New Yorker.

@Andrzej 

I'm with you on sports, and TBA wasn't a great answer to begin with.  But because sportballingnessitudinality just permeates the frea_ing culture here I'd somehow heard of Drew Brees (and of course the cute clue helped). 

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

@B even though I'm a Brit and not  much of a sports fan, i live in New Orleans,  and Drew Brees is an icon. He took the Saints to their first and only Super Bowl, which they won. In the many years he was the QB, the Saints were basically a good team - since he left, they've gone rapidly downhill.

@NOPenny
Okay.

Honestly not sure I would have been able to say football or baseball or basketball, and certainly not the city, team, or whether he were still playing.

I'm pretty happy about that.  :)

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

@Mike Gray's Analogy: "The lowing herd wind slowly o'er the lea" I'd bet it was neither a frolic nor gambol. Just bedtime in the country churchyard: "Beneath those rugged elms, that yew-tree's shade, Where heaves the turf in many a mould'ring heap, Each in his narrow cell for ever laid, The rude forefathers of the hamlet sleep." https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poems/44299/elegy-written-in-a-country-churchyard

@Mike 
As always, you're a man outstanding in his field.

@Al  in Pittsburgh 
I dig it Al.

@Patrick J. 

My first guess for 23A was NEO (near earth objects)
Oikofuge, It can mean a singular flower (or any type) or a bouquet. Or not flowers at all. English (and American, at that); go figure. https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/posy

(of any type)






typo type

@ŒôŒ±œÉœâŒΩ 

The clue as is makes sense though. You don't have to tell me because I SAW it myself.

We have clearance, Clarence. 

Roger, Roger. What's our vector, Victor?

@Mark Cousins

... and being an archer just means you can pick up a bow and arrow, it doesn't mean you're any good at it.

@Steve 

Tell me about it! I once saw a bow on sale in a sports store so I bought it on a whim. I quickly realized I couldn't even hit the target with most shots, from no more than 5 m away ü§£
@Steve You missed half of the answer, ACES is inside the word.

Mark Cousins,

"Roger that."



(Cringes)

@Andrzej 
Don't be disheartened, 5 miles is quite a distance for a bow.

@Steven M. 

Right? I stuck with suM for a long time, too.

@Steven M. 
For awhile after I'd solved the puzzle, I could not figure out how IAM was a correct answer. Finally, dawn broke over my Marble head.
@Andrzej - This photo shows a permanent radon detector at Warsaw University! https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/1f/Stanowisko_pomiaru_radonu_glebowego_wf_pw.jpg

@David Connell

Ye gods, indeed! Still, it is not part of building inspections to check radon levels here, neither for single-family houses nor for apartment buildings. In fact, the former are only ever subject to chimney inspections. The latter go through a more complex procedure every 5 years IIRC, but I've never heard of that having anything to do with radon (and I sat on the board of a housing cooperative so I think I would know).

@CTav 

I kept wondering if there was a rebus as I couldn't fit cinephile in there.
@Bill in Yokohama I first tried cinefile... heck it might be spelled that way somewhere. Or maybe not.

I wanted cinephile there, but that did not fit, and I knew it could not be spelled with an F. Thus I waited to get a word I apparently did not know from crosses. And Voila! CINEASTE. I will not remember this very weird-looking word though, I am quite sure.

@CTav Cin√©aste does primarily mean filmmaker‚Äîin French. The accent mark gives it away. In English, though, CINEAST(E) primarily means film buff: https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/cineast If the answer were in French, there would be a foreign language signal.
@CTav First definition at OED is "a lover of films or cinema." At M-W it's "a devotee of movies".

@Wilk 
Wow.  
That's pretty cool.  (I feel the same way about French)
Another tack would be to go live in Ohio from April to October...

@rt1 
Which ones are you talking about? UHAUL, FANTA and ESTEE Lauder all have international presences. And I think ETSY and SOLO cups are known outside the US as well.

@rt1
There were other US-centric clues/answers, as well, but the only three name brands I spotted were: U-HAUL, FANTA, and ESTE√âE Lauder. I‚Äôll grant that the first of those is probably unfamiliar to anyone who hasn‚Äôt lived in the US or absorbed it from some passing mention in a movie or something, but if anything, I think the soda brand is more popular outside North America‚ÄîI think I first encountered it when on vacation in mainland Europe, and it‚Äôs fairly common here in Japan‚Äîand I looked up the cosmetics brand‚Äôs global sales figures, and they‚Äôre pretty evenly spread out around the world.

@Vaer 
Ah, I missed ETSY and SOLO in my scanning of the grid. For what it‚Äôs worth, the shopping site apparently does have a Japanese presence, but I‚Äôve never heard of it outside of references in American media‚ÄîI think it became popular only after I moved abroad. I don‚Äôt think the Solo brand is widely available outside the US and Canada, but then again, how many people even in the US use or hear about those cups outside of depictions of (or possibly decades-ago participation in) college-age hijinks? Still, I wouldn‚Äôt think either of those should be too much of a challenge given crossings‚Äîcertainly more reasonable than, say, a random municipality in Connecticut that‚Äôs neither New Haven or Hartford.

@Nick
Though I grew up drinking orange Fanta, I also encountered it in Greece 30 years ago. My cousin had moved to Greece and when I visited, her Greek friends would go and "have a Fanta" at the seaside taverna in the afternoon.

@Nick When I was a kid I visited the Coca Cola museum in Atlanta. They had a big room where the wall was lined with soda fountains so you could try every global Fanta flavor, well over 100 choices, including "lychee nut" which stuck with me. Truly a global brand.

@Vaer 
Fewer brand names today than usual, I think. I knew UHAUL from TV, but never heard of SOLO. There are often brand names on Connections, which is why I am not able to get them all.

@Vaer 
I've just looked up tailgate party, definitely a US thing. I can't imagine people in the UK gathered in a car park eating and drinking! Car parks at events are usually completely full, and barbecuing would absolutely not be allowed. Wikipedia says even weddings? Surely not!

@Jane Wheelaghan 
Maybe sports fans in the UK do their pre-game festivities in pubs?

@Vaer 
Probably! Out of the rain.

@Oikofuge 

I truly respect the level of nitpicking in your first post. You wrote about things I neither know nor particularly care about - as it should be when we nitpick properly. Awesome ‚ù§Ô∏è

@Mean Old Lady 

I'm not big into nitpicking, as in: "Here's trivial but true stuff with which I aim to score some points just because I know it."

Rather, I'm genuinely intrigued that I encounter recurring solving difficulties because of obscure, subtle differences in usage between BrE and AmE. I can't think of another way I might have learned of the singular use of "posy".
And I'd be fascinated to know if the verb "to lase" is commonly used in the US for the process of zapping, as the cluing here suggests.

To steal an expression from George Bernard Shaw, I'm not dumb enough to confuse the customs of my tribe with the laws of nature. If it appeared that I was telling people that my usage is entirely correct while theirs is subtly wrong (which is what "nitpicking" implies to me) then I obviously need to phrase things better in future.

But perhaps I've just learned a subtle usage difference in the word "nitpicking".

@Jane Wheelaghan 

In Portuguese, Sunday is Domingo (Lord's day), but Monday is Segunda-feira (second day). The other weekdays follow the pattern, but Saturday is S√°bado, or Sabbath.  

In Greek, Sunday is ŒöœÖœÅŒπŒ±Œ∫ŒÆ (Kiriak√≠)(Lord's day), and Monday is ŒîŒµœÖœÑŒ≠œÅŒ± (Deft√©ra) (also second day).  Pattern continues, then Saturday is Œ£Œ¨Œ≤Œ≤Œ±œÑŒø (S√°vato), also Sabbath.

In Hebrew, Sunday is yom rishon. ◊ô◊ï◊ù ◊®◊ê◊©◊ï◊ü (first day), Monday yom sheni. ◊ô◊ï◊ù ◊©◊†◊ô (second day) and so on, but Saturday is ◊©◊ë◊™ (Shabbat). 

All the above derive from the seventh day being the Sabbath, which was Saturday.  Regardless, Russian is different, and don't even ask about Persian, which starts its week on Saturday, but the numerical names of the days derive from how many days after Saturday it is.

American calendars probably start the week on Sundays because they always have.  Simple as that.

@Vaer 
Multiple plague-sufferers, with multiple pockets, stuffed with multiple posies, each posy with multiple flowers.

But let's face it, most people today don't use the word "posy", without being deliberately cutesy-archaic, or referencing the nursery rhyme; they probably don't know exactly what it means, save that it's floral in nature.

Or maybe they're being elegantly minimalist, with a single, perfect bloom in their posy.

@Bill 
The connection with the plague and posies has long ago been discarded. The rhyme was used well before plague years, and is possibly pagan.
Our version
Ring-a ring-a roses
A pocket full of posies
A-tishoo A-tishoo
We all fall down.

@Bill - in the extremely rare cases of ‚Äúforte‚Äù and ‚Äúpiano‚Äù being indicated in the late 18th century, the letter f or p was written in bold but not in italic.

I trained my students to read music as it was actually written when it was actually written. Bach, Handel, and their contemporaries used the sharp sign to indicate a natural after a flat.
And they used cres. to indicate crescendo.

All notation comes from notation, it is ye same olde storie after all.

CIN√âASTE

@Mean Old Lady 

I knew the word and have heard it a fair amount.  As others have explained it's just used to mean movie lover / studier / voracious consumer.  (But apparently originally meant moviemaker.)  Highfalutin and sometimes applied mockingly, but it comes up in print reviews and such.  (Gourmand is probably a close analog.)  I probably wouldn't use it.

I kind of don't understand being perplexed about it.  We've borrowed, you know, a word or two from other languages.  Maybe three.  ;)

As to its "suffix" part, uh, so?  The stated  request was "any other word ending in -aste".  No need to lambaste.  :)

Interesting, MW lists 34 words ending in aste (7 "common") and 362 ending in ast.  Neat tool I didn't know they had; it must come in very handy for word game developers.

@Shari Coats 

I may have over-interpreted it, but to me the hint towards FIDO was the use of the word "classic" in the clue, Fido being derived from a classical language, Latin ("I trust"). Likewise that archetypal cat's name, Felix.

(There's a "careful usage" distinction between "classical" and "classic", just as there is between "historic" and "historical", but I find those subtleties are often unobserved.)

Or perhaps the implication was merely that "Fido" is a well-known dog name that has been around for centuries, without any implication of its classical origin.
